transcription.text: India in details, why is the West still funding Russia's war machine?
Why are these European countries still buying Russian gas and crude oil?
Why is the European Union still funding Putin's war?
Why is the USA still torturing so much from Russia?
Why?
Why?
My dear Americans, India has chosen independence.
It does not want to take orders from the USA.
Tell me.
If you truly support freedom, how can that
sound bad to you?
But of course, Trump posted this about India.
Read it carefully.
Looks like we've lost India and Russia to deepest, darkest China.
My dear Americans, as a European, I can tell you this.
The USA isn't the center of history, at best it can be considered a side-chapter.
The re-emergence of Bharat that you probably know as India is making the people with a colonial
mentality very, very uncomfortable.
They seem to be very jealous of India.
After all, to many in the global south, India in freedom, democracy and values seems
to be a far better role model than the Western colonial criminal states.
And what many in the West are now desperately targeting is India's strategic autonomy,
its sovereignty, its independence.
Take a look at this.
Surnister dreams of breaking India into pieces.
Yes, India's sovereignty is now more openly under attack from radicals in the Western
world.
Now please, stay with me.
You don't want to miss this.
And Dr. Jashankar's sharp remarks about Trump, to the USA's cruel original character that
many have no idea about.
This video presents point by point, mind boggling information you've likely never come across
anywhere else.
Point one.
So to start, let's find out who is truly stealing land and freedom.
I am going to try to scan the very soul of the USA like never before.
Take a look at this massive monument.
This is Von Rushmer, America's so-called National Memorial.
As symbol of the American spirit, a so-called shrine of democracy.
Even Trump recently posted this.
But probably, for Americans, nothing could be more embarrassing than this monument.
Yes, the brutal truth is that the USA is still not the rightful owner of Von Rushmer.
Yes, you heard that right.
Please listen carefully.
In true sense, this is not the USA, even today.
So what is it actually?
Well, the monument says in the area known as the Black Hills.
And yes, indigenous peoples are the rightful owners of the Black Hills.
So what happened to their land?
Well, after large deposits of gold were discovered in the Black Hills, the US government, acting
like a colonial criminal, ceased the land that had originally been guaranteed to indigenous
peoples.
A lot of gold was looted, I mean, extracted.
And in a major humiliation, the faces of these US presidents were carved onto stolen
land.
This is that remains sacred to indigenous peoples.
Even the colonizer's highest court, I mean, the US Supreme Court, has recognized this
treaty violation.
But has the USA returned this stolen land to the indigenous tribes?
The answer?
No.
Are the indigenous peoples the rightful owners still asking for their land to be returned?
The answer?
Yes.
And wait, wait, wait.
That's not even everything.
Who are these four US presidents anyway?
These describe here two slave owners and two who are hostile toward native Americans.
And these men, Teodor Roosevelt, well, he hunted animals for fun.
I explained that previously in this video.
And still, that's not all.
It is a monument whose sculptor has been described as a racist man with ties to the
K.A.
Yes.
You heard that right.
Ties to the K.A.
But of course, as expected, it is not even mentioned on the official page of this government
website, Americans sanitizing history as usual.
Dear American nationalists, what a shame.
This national monument, your so-called Shrine of Democracy, is not actually yours.
The land was stolen.
This site is sacred to indigenous peoples and it has been desecrated.
It's more like an active crime scene.
Dear American liberals, you dare preach religious freedom while your national memorial stands
carved into a mutilated sacred site.
Shame on you.
Here, your country openly glorifies colonization.
It openly glorifies slave owners.
How can anyone claim this monument is a matter of pride?
Instead, it looks more like a matter of shame.
A genocidal colonial criminal democracy deceitfully fooling the world by posing as a liberal
democracy seems like moral degradation and moral bankruptcy at their peak.
How can anyone still sacred indigenous land carve the faces of colonial oppressors into
a mountain where the rightful owners then native peoples pray and then have the audacity
to promote this active crime scene as both a tourist attraction and a national memorial?
And what a terrible heart-breaking American system where the colonized must beg for justice
in the colonizer's courts, courts built on stolen land.
If there is any shame, if Americans truly love freedom and justice, then please return
the stolen land, return the sale amount of gold that was taken, return the resources
looted with interest.
And then, the rightful owners, the indigenous peoples can decide whether they want to build
a Holocaust museum here instead.
Point two.
Now take a look.
How the European Union has been funding Russia's war machine?
LNG, the European Union, the largest buyer per chasing 51% of Russia's LNG exports,
pipeline gas.
Again, the European Union, the largest buyer per chasing 36% of Russia's pipeline gas.
Now let's see how the USA itself has been funding Russia's war machine.
Take a look.
This is from an official U.S. government website, Trade in Goals with Russia, year 2025.
Year 2024.
Imports.
Take a look.
Year 2023.
Year 2022.
The U.S. has continued to import Russian goods worth billions of dollars.
And don't forget, America was funding Russia even earlier.
After Crimea was annexed in 2014, U.S. trade with Russia continued.
In fact, imports were extremely huge, such as in 2021.
Wow.
This is the troop the U.S. cannot run away from.
Even Reuters has reported this.
So despite all these facts, why do they continue to blame India?
Well, this reflects the continued western practice of twisting history in real time.
Is it fair to say that Americans are afraid of competing against other great powers?
If so, that sounds like nothing but a loser's mentality.
Point three.
The troopers.
If India wanted, it could argue that the USA and some western countries have profited
from Indian Daps and earned blood money by selling weapons to Pakistan.
The troopers.
That if India wanted, it could also say that this or that western leader is in bed with
a chief of an army that is seen as a terrorism sponsor.
But India is India.
It is mature.
It behaves like a living civilization, not like the West.
And the West, well, from profiting in blood money through arms sales to Turkey, Pakistan
and many dictatorial regimes, the West has a long track record of profiting from wars
and human suffering.
Dr. Jishankar said, we have not had a US president who has conducted foreign policy as publicly
as the current one.
He added, and that's not limited to India.
President's Trump way of dealing with the world, even dealing with his own country, is
a very major departure from the traditional orthodox manner of doing so.
The American Empire shouldn't forget that it was India that dismantled or contributed
to the destruction of the British Empire.
So, who's next?
If India could show England its place, a western genocidal colonial criminal Christian
state, then if pushed too far, India can also have the USA find its rightful place on
the world map.
The USA shouldn't forget, empires can fall, but Farad's Dharma stands tall.
India will always have options.
It's not just about China and Russia, even the EU seems more than ready to engage with
India.
Read this recent article on Uron News.
As explained here, the European Union is an array against time to find new partners.
India, the world's most populous country, has emerged as the most desirable candidate.
Read this on paper, India takes all the boxes, a fast growing economy, a young labor force,
a burgeoning high tech sector, a strategic geographic location, and a democratic system.
So today, the European Union seems very keen to partner with India.
Do you see the irony that I see here?
Well, for Europe, especially the so-called former colonial powers, I have a message for
you.
Learn your karma lesson now.
Do not forget, it was your European colonialism or your European colonial mentality that
gave birth to the USA.
Today, when the USA pressures European countries or dictates terms to them, they should remember
this.
In a way, the USA is your own colonial product, and sometimes it bites you back.
Perhaps, you thought your colonialism would serve you forever.
You were wrong.
In the form of the USA, your colonial adventures actually created a hegemon or a bully, depending
on how you see it.
But it's never too late.
Give up your supremacist or racist attitude, partner with India on equal terms, and work
together to counter American pressure, economic or otherwise.
Yes, dear Europeans, the great country India, despite all the European colonial atrocities
against it, is kind enough and can save Europe from the USA.
A country that is, in many ways, Europe's own colonial product.
Yes, you heard that right.
India can save Europe again, just as Indian soldiers in World War II once saved Europe from
its own Nazism and Fascism.
Today, India can save Europe from Europe's own colonial product.
Point 4.
The empire claims moral superiority while profiting from blood money and while funding
Russia's war machine.
It talks about freedom while sitting on stolen land taken through genocide.
This is not just sheer hypocrisy and dishonesty, it is a systemic denial of history.
Dear Americans, we don't need your old world order.
What we need is an honest and equitable international partnership.
So will the USA apologize to India?
Well, whatever Trump is planning next, India is modern ready for the US president's tantrums.
So yes, before anyone dares to lecture India, learn some basics.
Karma was born in India, but the USA was born in debt.
When many in the West were learning how to count years, India was already counting Yogas.
Yes, I am talking about Bharat, a living civilization that rolled the Upanishads.
When the USA was not even in anyone's imagination.
Never forget that India's Dharma is eternal, while American colonialism is a crime with
an expiry date.
Never forget that India's Dharma does not bow down to thieves of land and freedom.
And yes, India's Dharma will outlive Western colonial criminal democracy.
And remember, the motherland of my two boys, my Bharat, is a thousands of years old living
civilization that does not take lectures from a 250 year old colonial product.
See you again.

visual_analysis.visual: The video begins with a black screen featuring white text that reads 'INDIA IN DETAILS.' This transitions to a distorted image of Mount Rushmore with an American flag overlay. A woman with shoulder-length blonde hair appears, wearing a patterned dress, standing in front of a wooden fence with a rural landscape in the background. Text at the bottom of the screen reads 'Russia's war machine?' The scene then shifts to a webpage displaying a bar graph titled 'Who is buying Russia's fossil fuels?' with arrows pointing to specific bars. The text below asks 'Why is the European Union still funding Russia despite record speed cutoff?' Another webpage is shown with the title 'U.S. imports from Russia' and a highlighted section stating 'U.S. imports from Russia totaled $2.50 billion in the first half of 2025 from $1.84 billion four years earlier, according to U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis data. Since then, U.S. States has imported $4.25 billion of Russian goods.' A news article headline reads 'EU devours Russian gas at record speed despite cutoff,' followed by a subheading questioning why the EU continues purchasing Russian gas. The woman reappears in front of the fence, continuing her commentary.

The video shows a woman standing in front of a wooden fence with a rural landscape in the background. She is wearing a patterned dress and has her hands on her hips. The scene then transitions to a screenshot of a tweet by Donald Trump, which reads 'Looks like we've lost India and Russia to deepest, darkest, China.' The woman reappears, now with her arms crossed, continuing her commentary. The background remains consistent with the rural landscape. The sequence concludes with a shot of three soldiers in uniform walking towards the camera, with an airplane visible in the background. The text on the screen mentions the resurgence of India, causing discomfort among certain individuals.

The video shows a close-up shot of a man in a maroon beret, followed by a wider shot of three men in similar attire standing in front of an airplane with 'India' written on it. The camera then zooms in on the face of one of the men. A man in a light-colored vest and dark pants descends the stairs of the airplane and shakes hands with another man in a suit. They walk together towards the right side of the frame. The scene shifts back to the woman in the patterned dress standing in front of the fence, with her arms crossed. Finally, a screenshot of a tweet by Gunther Fellnagel-Jahn appears, discussing India's role in a new world order. The tweet includes hashtags like #TianjinJiansummit and mentions dismantling NATO and inviting successor states to join.

The video presents a series of tweets and images related to geopolitical themes. A tweet from Gunther Fellnagel-Jahn appears, discussing a new world order led by China, Russia, and India. The tweet includes hashtags like #TianjinJiansummit and mentions dismantling NATO and inviting successor states to join. Another tweet from the same account is shown, calling for the dismantling of India into Modis as stabilized Ukraine and suggesting European Union countries join NATO to win against Russia and China. A black and white image of Dr. Jaishankar is displayed, followed by a list titled 'Please do not plagiarize/translate our work.' The list includes four points criticizing the USA and questioning its legitimacy. A cartoon image of Donald Trump is shown with a downward-trending graph representing the Indian Rupee, accompanied by text questioning who truly owns land and freedom.

The video presents a series of visuals related to Mount Rushmore. A cartoon image of Donald Trump with a downward-trending graph and Indian rupee coins suggests a financial theme. A woman dressed in traditional Indian attire holds a trident against the backdrop of the Indian flag, symbolizing strength or power. A distorted image of Donald Trump appears, possibly indicating a negative portrayal. Mount Rushmore is shown at sunset, transitioning to a wider view during daytime. The text overlay mentions Mount Rushmore as a national memorial and a symbol of American spirit. A tweet from Donald Trump is displayed, featuring Mount Rushmore, which is then zoomed in on. The text discusses the monument's significance and ownership. These visuals collectively emphasize the cultural and political importance of Mount Rushmore, with references to both historical and contemporary perspectives.

The video shows a series of frames related to Mount Rushmore. A tweet from Donald Trump overlaid on an image of Mount Rushmore reads 'Yes, the brutal truth that the USA is still not the rightful owner of Mount Rushmore. Yes, you heard that right!' This is followed by a scene where a woman stands in front of a wooden fence, speaking to the camera. She appears to be discussing the ownership of Mount Rushmore. The video transitions to a webpage titled 'Mount Rushmore' from the National Park Service website. The page includes a photo of Mount Rushmore and text describing its location and significance. The text mentions that Mount Rushmore is located in the Black Hills of South Dakota and is sacred to the Lakota people. The woman continues to speak in front of the fence, emphasizing the historical context and the rightful ownership of the land by indigenous peoples. The video then returns to the webpage, highlighting the text about the discovery of gold in the Black Hills and the subsequent seizure of the land by the U.S. government. The woman reappears, continuing her discussion about the historical injustices and the ongoing struggle for the return of the land to its rightful owners.

The video shows a series of frames that provide information about Mount Rushmore. A screenshot of a webpage titled 'Is Mount Rushmore on sacred Native American land?' includes an image of Mount Rushmore with an American flag. The text discusses the historical context of the Black Hills and the treaties signed between the Lakota and Nakota tribes and the United States government. Another webpage from the United Nations Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner details the history of the Black Hills and the gold discovery that led to the area being passed to the United States. The text highlights the colonial actions taken by the U.S. government. The woman in the patterned dress appears briefly, standing in front of the fence with her arms crossed. She seems to be summarizing or commenting on the information displayed. The visuals focus on the historical and legal aspects of Mount Rushmore's location, emphasizing its significance to Native American communities.

The video shows a woman standing in front of a wooden fence with her arms crossed. She appears to be speaking, but since we are focusing on visuals, we note her attire and posture. The background includes greenery and a house, suggesting a residential setting. The scene transitions to a news article headline that reads 'US should return stolen land to Indian tribes, says United Nations.' This headline is accompanied by an image of a person sitting outside a building, possibly indicating a Native American individual. The text below the headline discusses the UN's call for action against racial discrimination felt by Native Americans. The video then returns to the woman, who continues to speak with her arms crossed. Her expression and gestures suggest she is emphasizing a point. The background remains consistent with the earlier scene. Another news article headline appears, stating 'The national memorial draws 3 million visitors a year.' This headline is accompanied by an image of two individuals in traditional Native American attire standing before Mount Rushmore. The text below highlights the site's focus on Native American oppression. Finally, the video shows a screenshot of a Britannica article titled 'Is Mount Rushmore on sacred Native American land?' The article discusses the history of the Great Sioux Nation and mentions two slave owners among the presidents depicted on Mount Rushmore. The video concludes this segment with a still image of the article, emphasizing the controversial nature of the monument.

The video presents a series of frames that focus on Mount Rushmore and related historical content. A screenshot from Britannica appears, questioning whether Mount Rushmore is on sacred Native American land. The image shows the monument with red circles highlighting the faces of the presidents carved into the mountain. Below this, text describes the Great Sioux Nation's forced surrender of their territory and mentions two slave owners among the presidents depicted. The video transitions to a YouTube video thumbnail featuring a woman sitting in a yellow chair. The title of the video is 'Dirty Teddy Bear & Eunuchs | Shashi Tharoor SPEAKS,' and it includes the names Karolina Gowaski and Brilliant Takdeow. This suggests a discussion or commentary related to the topic at hand. The scene then shifts back to the woman standing in front of the fence, who continues her presentation. The video cuts to another screenshot from The Washington Post, discussing the depiction of America's greatest presidents on Mount Rushmore, mentioning sculptor Gutzon Borglum's ties to the KKK. The article highlights Borglum's racist mindset and his role in creating the monument. Finally, the video shows a black-and-white photo of Mount Rushmore under construction, followed by another screenshot from The Washington Post, focusing on Borglum's forgotten ties to white supremacy and his role in carving the monument. The text emphasizes the controversial history surrounding the creation of Mount Rushmore, linking it to themes of racism and colonialism.

The video presents a series of frames that focus on Mount Rushmore and related content. A webpage titled 'Sculptor Gutzon Borglum' is shown, featuring a black-and-white photo of Borglum wearing a hat. The text provides biographical details about him, including his birthplace and early life. This scene emphasizes Borglum's role in creating Mount Rushmore. A YouTube video thumbnail appears, titled 'Mount Rushmore: A proud symbol of America,' uploaded by CBS Evening News. The thumbnail shows a man in a suit standing at a podium with the Mount Rushmore monument in the background. This suggests a discussion or presentation about the monument's significance as a symbol of American pride. The video returns to the woman standing in front of the fence, continuing her commentary. She gestures with her hands, indicating emphasis on her points. The scene then shifts to a wide shot of Mount Rushmore, showing the monument against a cloudy sky. This visual reinforces the ongoing discussion about the monument's controversial nature.

The video shows a series of visuals that emphasize the controversial nature of Mount Rushmore. The woman reappears, standing in front of the wooden fence, continuing her commentary. The scene then transitions to a close-up of Mount Rushmore, overlaid with an American flag, which fades into a night sky filled with fireworks. This imagery suggests a celebration or commemoration, but the context implies a critique of this celebration due to the monument's contentious history. The video shows a wide shot of the Mount Rushmore visitor center entrance, bustling with tourists. This scene highlights the monument's status as a popular tourist attraction, juxtaposed with the ongoing debate over its historical significance. The presence of many visitors underscores the monument's enduring appeal despite the controversy surrounding it. The sequence continues with a news article headline stating 'Trump 'not welcome' at Mt. Rushmore,' indicating political tensions related to the site. This is followed by a courtroom scene where a judge gestures while seated at a desk, symbolizing legal challenges or discussions about the monument's future. These visuals collectively convey the complex and multifaceted nature of Mount Rushmore, blending historical, cultural, and political dimensions.

The video presents a series of frames that convey a strong message against the glorification of Mount Rushmore. The woman reappears, standing in front of the wooden fence, continuing her commentary. A news article headline reads 'Trump 'not welcome' Native American leader at Mt Rushmore,' accompanied by an image of Mount Rushmore. This sets the stage for the critique of the monument's significance. The scene shifts to a judge in a courtroom setting, symbolizing the legal challenges faced by indigenous communities. The judge is seen gesturing, possibly indicating a ruling or decision related to land rights. The video then transitions to a view of the Supreme Court building, reinforcing the theme of legal battles and the struggle for justice. This is followed by another news article titled 'US should return stolen land to Indian tribes, says United Nations,' which emphasizes international pressure on the US to address historical injustices. Throughout these frames, the video uses text overlays and images to highlight the ongoing debate over Mount Rushmore's legacy. The consistent presence of Mount Rushmore in the background serves as a reminder of the monument's controversial status. The scenes collectively underscore the video's argument against the glorification of colonial oppression and the demand for justice for indigenous peoples.

The video shows a woman standing in front of a wooden fence, speaking directly to the camera. The background includes trees and a grassy area. The scene transitions to a webpage displaying statistics about Russia's exports. The highlighted text indicates that the European Union (EU) was the largest buyer of Russian LNG, purchasing 51% of Russia's LNG exports. Additionally, the EU was the largest buyer of Russian pipeline gas, purchasing 36% of Russia's pipeline gas. The woman continues to speak in front of the fence throughout this segment.

The video begins with a screenshot of a webpage titled 'Trade in Goods with Russia.' The page displays tables showing U.S. exports, imports, and trade balance with Russia for the years 2023, 2024, and 2025. The camera zooms in on the table for 2024 imports, highlighting specific figures. A woman with shoulder-length blonde hair, wearing a patterned dress, appears standing in front of a wooden fence with a rural landscape in the background. She gestures with her hands while speaking. The scene then transitions to a handshake between two men in suits at a table with documents, followed by a close-up of a table displaying financial data. Finally, a news article headline from Reuters is shown, stating 'Three years into war, US and Europe keep billions in trade with Russia.'

The video shows two men in suits shaking hands over a table with documents. The camera then focuses on a table displaying financial figures, highlighting a total of 29,683.3. Following this, a Reuters news article titled 'Three years into war, US and Europe keep billions in trade with Russia' is shown, dated August 6, 2023. The article discusses U.S. imports from Russia, mentioning a $25.4 billion figure since January 2022. The scene then transitions back to the woman standing in front of a fence, continuing her commentary.

The video shows flags of various countries, including Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, arranged horizontally. This arrangement suggests a focus on BRICS nations, which are known for their economic and political significance. The scene then transitions to a close-up shot of two men in suits engaged in conversation. The man on the left appears to be smiling, indicating a positive interaction. The video then displays a list titled 'Please do not plagiarize/translate our work,' with four points addressing different aspects of Western influence and criticism. The text is highlighted in yellow. The scene then features a woman standing in front of a rural landscape with a wooden fence. She is wearing a patterned dress and has her arms crossed, suggesting a serious or contemplative demeanor. Finally, the video displays a news article headline from Al Jazeera, questioning why former US President Trump aided Navarro in criticizing Indian Prime Minister Modi's relationship with Putin and Xi. This headline is accompanied by images of two individuals, one of whom is identified as Peter Navarro.

The video shows a news article headline questioning why Trump aided Navarro in asking Modi why he is 'getting into bed with Putin and Xi.' The article includes images of two individuals, likely related to the discussion. The scene transitions to a man in military attire sitting at a table with Donald Trump, suggesting a meeting or discussion between them. The background features a digital circuit pattern, adding a technological or strategic context to the scene. The video displays a webpage titled 'Profits of War: Corporate Beneficiaries of the Post-9/11 Pentagon Spending Surge,' highlighting financial data related to war profits. A man is shown speaking into a microphone, possibly addressing an audience or giving a speech. The setting appears formal, indicating a significant event or announcement.

The video shows a screenshot of a webpage titled 'Trade in Goods with Russia,' displaying tables showing U.S. exports, imports, and trade balance with Russia for the years 2023, 2024, and 2025. The camera zooms in on the table for 2024 imports, highlighting specific figures. A woman with shoulder-length blonde hair, wearing a patterned dress, appears standing in front of a wooden fence with a rural landscape in the background. She gestures with her hands while speaking. The scene then transitions to a handshake between two men in suits at a table with documents, followed by a close-up of a table displaying financial data. Finally, a news article headline from Reuters is shown, stating 'Three years into war, US and Europe keep billions in trade with Russia.'
